context: [8] Here, this extracytoplasmic loop region in H. pyloricontains two adjacent histidine residues which have a presumed pKa of âˆ¼6.0, about the same pH that activates the cytoplasmic urease.  [9] In addition, there is a pair of carboxylic acids in this loop. [10] These four amino acids are predicted to be the major immunogenic determinants in this region. [11] Protonation of these histidines could result in hydrogen bonding with the carboxylic acids enabling urea transport across the membrane domain. [12] Substitution of one or the other of these particular amino acids might result in the loss of immunoreactivity. [13] If this has occurred in H. mustelae, it may explain the difference in the urease activation pH. Cloning and sequencing of the ureIgene of H. mustelae would be able to support this hypothesis. [14] Failure to generate a ureI PCR product fromH.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is indirectly related to protonation through the mechanism of urea transport across the membrane in H. pylori. The protonation of adjacent histidine residues, which have a pKa around 6.0, is suggested to facilitate hydrogen bonding with carboxylic acids, thereby enabling urea transport. This indicates a biochemical interaction where protonation plays a role in the functionality of urea transport mechanisms, although the relationship is not extensively detailed.
